heading: whopping profits for microsoft
subheading: the numbers are in for microsoft's latest quarter, and they're big -- much bigger than wall street projected. so what's new?
author: reuters
text: software giant microsoft tuesday said strong personal computer sales and year 2000-related spending drove quarterly earnings 75 percent higher than in the same period a year earlier, far exceeding even the highest wall street estimates. microsoft said it earned us$1.98 billion, or 73 cents per diluted share, in its fiscal second quarter, up from $1.13 billion, or 42 cents, a year earlier. revenues rose 38 percent to $4.94 billion from $3.59 billion.on average, wall street analysts estimated microsoft would earn 59 cents a share in the quarter ended 31 december, with the most optimistic estimating the company would come in with earnings of 61 cents, according to first call, an investment research firm."all in all, it was a rather stunning quarter," said rick sherlund, an analyst at goldman sachs.the results were released after the close of nasdaq trading, where microsoft rose $5.88 to close at a record $155.63 in a very active session. in after-hours trading, microsoft's stock jumped nearly $8 to $163.25 a share, traders said.microsoft chief financial officer greg maffei credited strong growth in personal computer shipments with fueling broad demand for the company's core products, including the high-end windows nt family of products and the office suite of basic business applications.he also said sales "spiked due in part to demand caused by year 2000 concerns," because people are replacing older systems to ensure their computers read the dates correctly after 1999.
